episodes.title: The Vrata Rules
episodes.description: A 41-day Hindu purification practice becomes a lens for understanding transformation, discipline, and the sacred rhythms that shape human behavior across cultures.
episodes.longDescription: What starts as an overheard conversation about dietary restrictions leads us deep into the world of Vrata—ancient Hindu observances that range from simple fasting to elaborate 41-day purification rituals. We explore how these practices create containers for transformation, and what they reveal about the human need for structured renewal.

episodes.title: What Extraction Loses
episodes.description: When we extract knowledge from its context, what gets left behind? An exploration of information, wisdom, and the spaces between.
episodes.longDescription: A conversation about coffee extraction leads to deeper questions about how we extract meaning from experience. We examine the difference between information and wisdom, and what we lose when we try to distill complex realities into simple takeaways.

episodes.title: Responders vs Non-Responders
episodes.description: Why do some people respond to treatments, practices, and experiences while others don't? The science of individual variation.
episodes.longDescription: An overheard debate about why meditation works for some but not others opens up a fascinating exploration of responders versus non-responders in medicine, psychology, and beyond. We discover that individual variation is far more significant than most interventions acknowledge.

episodes.title: The Pinocchio Problem
episodes.description: What does it mean to become 'real'? From AI consciousness to authentic selfhood, we explore the boundaries of genuine experience.
episodes.longDescription: A casual reference to Pinocchio sparks an unexpected journey into questions of authenticity and consciousness. What makes something—or someone—real? We examine this question through the lens of AI, psychology, and philosophy.

episodes.title: How Learning Actually Works
episodes.description: Everything you think you know about learning is probably wrong. The neuroscience of how we actually acquire and retain knowledge.
episodes.longDescription: A frustrated student's complaint about forgetting everything leads us into the counterintuitive science of learning. We discover why difficulty enhances retention, why cramming fails, and why the best learning often feels like the worst.

episodes.title: The Labor Question
episodes.description: As automation transforms work, we ask: what is labor for? A meditation on meaning, machines, and the future of human contribution.
episodes.longDescription: Two workers discussing job automation inspire a deep dive into the labor question. Beyond economics, we explore the psychological and existential dimensions of work. What happens when machines can do everything we can do—only better?

episodes.title: Peak Reality
episodes.description: Have we passed 'peak reality'? An examination of authenticity, simulation, and what counts as real experience in an increasingly mediated world.
episodes.longDescription: A nostalgic conversation about 'the way things used to be' leads to a provocative thesis: perhaps we've passed peak reality. We explore how mediated experiences have transformed our relationship with the real, and whether that matters.

episodes.title: Optimizing Metrics, Destroying Systems
episodes.description: Goodhart's Law in action: when a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure. How optimization can destroy what it aims to improve.
episodes.longDescription: A manager's complaint about hitting all the numbers but missing the point opens a window into Goodhart's Law and its cousins. We examine how the drive to optimize metrics often destroys the very systems those metrics were meant to measure.

episodes.title: Irreversible Windows
episodes.description: Season finale: Some doors, once opened, cannot be closed. We explore critical periods, irreversible changes, and the moments that define us forever.
episodes.longDescription: In our final episode, we examine irreversible windows—those critical periods in development, technology, and society where changes become permanent. From childhood development to AI advancement, we ask: what windows are closing now, and what does that mean for the future?
